tn.text: Continuing the story of how the new Christians shared their belongings with other believers, Luke tells about two believers, Ananias and Sapphria. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline to tell a new part of the story.
"his wife also knew that he kept back part of the sale money"

tn.ref: laid it at the apostles' feet
tn.text: This means that they presented to money to the apostles. AT: "presented it to the apostles" or "gave it to the apostles." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:34|4:35]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
If your language does not use rhetorical questions, you may reword these as statements.

tn.ref: why has Satan filled your heart to lie ... land?
tn.text: Peter uses this question to rebuke Ananias. AT: "you should not have let Satan convince you to lie ... land" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])

Here the word "heart" refers to the will and emotions. Possible meanings are 1) "Satan completely controlled you" (UDB) or 2) "Satan convinced you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])

tn.ref: to lie to the Holy Spirit and to keep back part of the price
tn.text: This implies that Ananias had told the apostles that he was giving the entire amount that he had received from selling his land. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: While it remained unsold, did it not remain your own?
tn.text: Peter uses this question to rebuke Ananias. AT: "While it remained unsold, it was your own possession" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"While you had not sold it"

tn.ref: And after it was sold, was it not in your control?
tn.text: Peter uses this question to rebuke Ananias. AT: "And after it was sold, you had control over the money that you received" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "And after you sold it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: How is it that you thought of this thing in your heart?
tn.text: Peter used this question to rebuke Ananias. Here the word "heart" refers to the will and emotions. AT: "You should not have thought of doing this thing" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: fell down and breathed his last
tn.text: Ananias fell down because he died; he did not die because he fell down. AT: "died and fell to the ground" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
"Ananias' wife came in" or "Sapphira came in"
"that her husband had died"
"for this much money." This refers to the amount of money that Ananias had given to the apostles.
This is the end of the part of the story about Ananias and Sapphira.
Here the word "you" is plural and refers to both Ananias and Sapphira. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])

tn.ref: How is it that you have agreed together to test the Spirit of the Lord?
tn.text: Peter asks this question to rebuke Sapphira. AT: "You should not have agreed together to test the Spirit of the Lord!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
"the two of you have agreed together"

tn.ref: to test the Spirit of the Lord
tn.text: Here the word "test" means to challenge or to prove. They were trying to see if they could get away with lying to God without receiving punishment.

tn.ref: the feet of those who have buried your husband
tn.text: Here the phrase "the feet" refers to the men. AT: "the men who have buried your husband" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
This means that when she died, she fell on the floor in front of Peter. This expression should not be confused with falling down at a person's feet as a sign of humility.
"died." See how you translated this phrase with reference to Ananias in [[:en:bible:notes:act:05:03|5:5]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_euphemism]])
Luke continues to tell what happens in the early days of the church.
Here the words "They" and "they" refer to the believers.

tn.ref: Many signs and wonders were taking place among the people through the hands of the apostles
tn.text: or "Many signs and wonders took place among the people through the hands of the apostles." This can be stated in active form. AT: "The apostles performed many signs and wonders among the people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"supernatural events and miraculous deeds." See how you translated these terms in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:22|2:22]]

tn.ref: through the hands of the apostles
tn.text: Here the word "hands" refers to the apostles. AT: "through the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

This was a covered walkway that consisted of rows of pillars that supported a roof, and which people named after king Solomon. See how you translated "the porch that is called Solomon's" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:03:11|3:11]].

tn.ref: they were held in high esteem by the people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "the people held the believers in high esteem" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "they" refers to the people who lived in Jerusalem.

tn.ref: more believers were being added to the Lord
tn.text: This could be stated in active form. AT: "more people were believing in the Lord." See how you translated "were added" in [[:en:bible:notes:act:02:40|2:41]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: his shadow might fall on some of them
tn.text: It is implied that God would heal them if Peter's shadow touched them. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"those whom unclean spirits had afflicted"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "God healed them all" or "the apostles healed them all" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
The religious leaders began to persecute the believers.
This begins a contrasting story. You may translate this in the way that your language introduces a contrasting narrative.
Here the phrase "rose up" means that the high priest decided to take action, not that he stood up from a seated position. AT: "the high priest took action" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This could be stated in active form. AT: "they became very jealous" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])

This means that they seized the apostles by force. They would have ordered guards to do this. AT: "had the guards arrest the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the words "them" and "they" refer to the apostles.

tn.ref: in the temple ... into the temple
tn.text: They did not go into the temple building where only the priests were allowed. AT: "in the temple courtyard ... into the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: all the words of this Life
tn.text: This is a reference to the gospel message that the apostles had already proclaimed. Possible meanings are 1) "all this message of eternal life" or 2) "the whole message of this new way of living"
"as it began to be light." Although the angel led them out of the jail during the night, the sun was rising by the time the apostles reached the temple courtyard.

tn.ref: sent to the jail to have the apostles brought
tn.text: This implies someone went to the jail. AT: "sent someone to the jail to bring the apostles" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])

The words "no one" refer to the apostles. This implies that there was no one else in the jail cell besides the apostles. AT: "we did not find them inside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here the word "you" is plural and refers to the captain of the temple and the chief priests. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"they were very puzzled" or "they were very confused"
"concerning the words they had just heard" or "concerning these things"
"and what would happen as a result"
They did not go into the part of the temple building where only the priests were allowed. AT: "standing in the temple courtyard" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
The captain and the officers bring the apostles before the Jewish religious council.

The word "they" in this section refers to the captain and the officers. In the phrase "feared that the people might stone them" the word "them" refers to the captain and the officers. All other occurrences of "them" in this chunk refer to the apostles.
Here the word "you" is plural and refers to the apostles. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_you]])
"they were afraid"

Here the word "name" refers to the person of Jesus. AT: "not to speak anymore about this person, Jesus." See how you translated this in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:15|4:17]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have filled Jerusalem with your teaching
tn.text: This idiom means that they have taught everyone in Jerusalem.  AT: "you have taught everyone in Jerusalem about him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole]])

tn.ref: desire to bring this man's blood upon us
tn.text: Here the word "blood" refers to Jesus' death. This is an idiomatic way of saying that they are responsible for killing him. AT: "desire to make us responsible for this man's death" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Here the word "We" refers to  the apostles, and not to the audience. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive]])
Peter spoke on behalf of all of the apostles when he said the following words.

tn.ref: by hanging him on a tree
tn.text: Here Peter uses the word "tree" to refer to the cross which was made out of wood. AT: "by hanging him on a cross" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: give repentance to Israel, and forgiveness of sins
tn.text: The words "repentance" and "forgiveness" can be translated as verbs. AT: "give the people of Israel an opportunity to repent and have God forgive their sins" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_abstractnouns]])
The word "Israel" refers to the Jewish people. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"those who submit to God's authority"
Gamaliel addresses the council members.

tn.ref: Gamaliel, a teacher of the law, who was honored by all the people
tn.text: Luke introduces Gamaliel and provides background information about him. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_participants]] and  [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])

tn.ref: who was honored by all the people
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "whom all the people honored" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: commanded the apostles to be taken outside
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "commanded the guards to take the apostles outside" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"think carefully about" (UDB) or "be cautious about." Gamaliel was warning them not to do something that they would later regret.
Possible meanings are 1) "Theudas rebelled" (UDB) or 2) "Theudas appeared."
"claiming to be somebody important"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "People killed him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])

tn.ref: all who had been obeying him were scattered
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. AT: "all the people scattered who had been obeying him" or "all who had been obeying him went in different directions" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
This means that they did not do what they had planned to do.
"After Theudas"

tn.ref: in the days of the census
tn.text: "during the time of the census"

tn.ref: drew away some people after him
tn.text: This means that he persuaded some people to rebel with him against the Roman government. AT: "caused many people to follow him" or "caused many people to join him in rebellion" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
Gamaliel finishes addressing the council members. Though they beat the apostles, command them not to teach about Jesus, and let them go, the disciples continue to teach and preach.

tn.ref: keep away from these men and let them alone
tn.text: Gamaliel is telling the Jewish leaders no to punish the apostles any more or to put them back in jail. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])

tn.ref: if this plan or work is of men
tn.text: "if men have devised this plan or are doing this work"
This can be stated in active form. AT: "someone will overthrow it" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here the word "it" refers to "this plan or work." AT: "if God has devised this plan or commanded these men to do this work" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_ellipsis]])
This can be stated in active form. AT: "So Gamaliel persuaded them" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here first word "they" refers to the council members. The rest of the words "them," "They," and "they" refer to the apostles.

tn.ref: they called the apostles in and beat them
tn.text: The council members would have ordered the temple guards to do these things. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: to speak in the name of Jesus
tn.text: Here "name" refers to the authority of Jesus. AT: "to speak anymore in the authority of Jesus." See how you translated a similar phrase in [[:en:bible:notes:act:04:15|4:18]]. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: they were counted worthy to suffer dishonor for the Name
tn.text: The apostles rejoiced because God had honored them by letting the Jewish leaders dishonor them. This can be stated in active form. AT: "God had counted them worthy to suffer dishonor for the Name" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "the Name" refers to Jesus. AT: "for Jesus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"After that day, every day." This phrase marks what the apostles did every day through the following days.

tn.ref: in the temple and from house to house
tn.text: They did not go into the temple building where only the priests went. AT: "in the temple courtyard and in different people's houses" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
